fields.description: In EDGE we should validate that the specified private IP addresses are valid for use with the specified subnets.
fields.summary: EDGE network JSON property update should fail when private IPs are not valid for subnets

comments.body: [~nurmi], please comment on whether a configuration with the same private IPs for multiple clusters is ever valid.

All,

It could be valid, if the clusters are using the same private subnet.  However, if the clusters are using different subnets, they must necessarily be distinct.  

The back-end does no checking on this issue, as the private IP selection process moved up into the CLC for EDGE.  If a change is made to permit a configuration where each cluster has the same range of private IPs (i.e. one range is specified and the CLC then selects from that range independent from cluster), then i additional checks should be done to ensure that this is only allowed when the cluster private subnets in question are identical.

-D
[~nurmi], why do the subnets need to be identical? is it not sufficient that the private IPs used in a cluster are valid for its subnet? (and not in use elsewhere)

[~sjones], are you referring to case where one subnet is a superset of the other, and a list of private IPs falls within the subset subnet?  If so, then you are correct, there could be a valid config where one range falls within two different subnets.  This would be an unusual (I think?) setup, but you are correct that it could be valid.

From a configuration/understanding perspective, I feel that having distinct private ranges per cluster is both expressive enough for actual deployments, and simple to describe (since whether you are using different or same subnets wouldn't effect the description of configuration).  We can say 'private IP ranges for each cluster must be distinct' and it covers all cases.  Otherwise, there are caveats that will have to be enumerated (I think).

Technically, there could be valid (from a networking perspective) cases where one range of private IPs would be valid for multiple clusters each with distinct subnets.

-D

Not sure how to proceed at this point as I do not agree that we should force different private IPs to be configured for clusters when there is no technical need to do so.

The specific use case here is when there is a single subnet in use for multiple clusters, if the user must configure the private IP ranges for each then they must adjust this as they add clusters which may not be trivial (may involve terminating instances to free IPs for use in a new cluster)

[~sjones]

| The specific use case here is when there is a single subnet in use for multiple clusters, if the user must configure the private 
| IP ranges for each then they must adjust this as they add clusters which may not be trivial (may involve terminating 
| instances to free IPs for use in a new cluster)

that is a legit scenario in favor of a single range, but only if you have over-provisioned your range of IPs for your cluster in the first place.  If it were a cloud we were setting up, we would match the number of IPs that are available for each cluster to the maximum number of VMs my cluster will be provisioned to support, in which case the list will not change even if future clusters are added.  In the case where a user has over-provisioned private IPs for a cluster and then wishes to add another cluster and re-allocate the IPs, then this would require a network reconfiguration step, indeed.

I don't feel strongly about this issue, and won't argue to constrain the solution - in fact if you believe it is better to add the expressiveness of allowing the same range for multiple clusters I'm fine with that, but we should then be careful to document the caveats and/or ensure the error conditions are sent back to the user clearly.

-D

just to be sure we're on the same page - if you implement a way to have one range that covers multiple subnets (or clusters), I do feel strongly that we must still allow the user to specify non-overlapping private list/ranges (per cluster) to support the scenario that I've described (where you *want* the behavior of a specific given list per cluster, even if the clusters are in the same (or overlapping) subnets).   Is that right?

_D

Right, you must be able to configure the private IPs for each cluster, I just don't want to make it a hard requirement to do so. Configuration of private IPs is actually optional and defaults to all valid IPs in the subnet being used (the calculated IP range(s) is included in the network broadcast)

We will now reject network configuration property updates when the given private IP addresses are not valid for the given subnet.

As noted above, specifying the private IP addresses is optional, the default is to use all the IPs in the subnet (other than the gateway, broadcast, etc)

[~nurmi], due to this fix we no longer include information for a cluster in the network broadcast when that cluster does not have a subnet configured (this relates to the validation mentioned in EUCA-8925)

[~sjones], I believe that I understand, but to be clear - if a cluster ( in the configuration JSON ) does not have a subnet configured, then that cluster will not be usable to run VMs (does not go to ENABLED?), since without a subnet, there is not a way to decide which private IPs the cluster can use for VMs - is that right?

currently, the back-end validation for the XML document will fail if a cluster is present in the XML without a subnet declared.  If I understand correctly, this means that the XML will not contain any mention of a cluster unless a subnet has been defined for that cluster - is that right?

D

[~nurmi], there is no change to the enabled state of the cluster due to this fix. The private IP checking is performed at configuration time, not when instances are launched, so it is currently possible that a private IP will be assigned (if private IPs are declared outside of any cluster)

The cluster property element and descendants will be omitted from the XML document if it does not have a subnet defined, other information for that cluster may be present if there were any (instances running in that cluster for example)
